news.title: Prominent Mutare Businessman Dies In Horror Crash
news.content:
By A Correspondent-prominent Mutare transport operator Mr Godfrey Chikosi, and five other have died in a tragic road accident that occurred last night at the Himalaya-Turn Off along the Mutare-Chimanimani Road.

The accident happened around 11pm, and one survivor is currently receiving treatment at Victoria Chitepo Provincial Hospital with severe injuries.

Mr Chikosi was among the four victims who died on the spot.

Two others died at hospital.

Acting Manicaland police spokesman, Assistant Inspector Wiseman Chinyoka was not immediately available for a comment.

However, fellow transporter, Mr Isau Mupfumi confirmed Mr Chikosis death, and deployed a team to visit the accident scene early this morning.

-Manica Post

news.title: 11 People Perish In Two Separate Road Accidents
news.content:
By A Correspondent

Eleven people have died in two separate road accidents in Mutare and along the HarareNyamapanda Highway between Thursday night and Friday morning.

In Mutare, six people lost their lives when a Toyota GD6, driven by prominent transport operator Godfrey Chikosi, veered off the road and rolled several times near the Himalaya Turn-Off, close to 9 Miles along the MutareMasvingo Road.

The crash occurred around 11 PM on Wednesday. Four people, including Chikosi, died on the spot, while two others succumbed to their injuries later. The vehicle had seven occupants. The sole survivor was rushed to Victoria Chitepo Provincial Hospital with serious injuries.

According to a state media report, Chikosi lost control of the vehicle before it veered off the road and overturned.

Chikosi sustained serious head injuries, together with Vincent Musepa and two ladies only identified by their first names as Patience and Melissa. Three other passengers were seriously injured and rushed to Victoria Chitepo Provincial Hospital, where sadly two died on admission. As we speak, one victim is battling for his life, a source told state media.

Another source added that Chikosi was driving towards Masvingo when, near the 42km peg close to Himalaya Turn-Off, he lost control. The Toyota GD6 swerved to the left, struck a concrete road sign, and overturned several times before landing on its roof.

The Zimbabwe Republic Police (ZRP) confirmed the accident in a statement shared on X (formerly Twitter). Police said four people were killed in the crash, stating:

The ZRP confirms a fatal road traffic accident which occurred at the 46 kilometre peg along Mutare  Masvingo Road on 28/08/25. A Toyota Fortuner GD6 vehicle with seven occupants on board veered off the road, hit a concrete road signpost, and overturned several times before landing on its roof. Resultantly, four people died on the spot while three others were injured. The bodies of the victims were taken to Victoria Chitepo Provincial hospital mortuary while the injured are admitted at the same institution.

Separately, on Friday, a private kombi carrying passengers, bricks, and tombstones overturned along the HarareNyamapanda Highway, killing five people on the spot.

news.title: Econet Pushes For Network Upgrade
news.content:
By Business Correspondent  The struggling Econet Wireless has announced plans to roll out a 5G network, in what it claims is a major step towards improving its services. The announcement, however, comes at a time when the company faces widespread criticism over deteriorating network quality, exorbitant tariffs, and poor customer care.

Econet deputy chief executive officer, Mr Roy Chimanikire, revealed the plans at the companys exhibition stand during the ongoing Zimbabwe Agricultural Show (ZAS). He said Econet has already deployed 300 5G base stations as of July 2025, extending high-speed connectivity to over 500,000 customers. Millions of others remain on 4G (LTE), with some still dependent on outdated 3G services.

Chimanikire described the rollout as a step towards positioning Zimbabwe for a full digital economy, saying 5Gs potential goes beyond faster internet speeds to transformative uses in business and industry through the Internet of Things (IoT). He highlighted applications such as smart water management, drone-assisted agriculture, and AI-driven smart parking, as well as the companys new chatbot,Yamurai, which communicates in Shona and Ndebele to resolve customer queries.

Its about the next level of technology in terms of efficiency, scalability, and speed of delivering products and services, he said.

Despite the upbeat messaging, Econets announcement comes against a backdrop of mounting customer dissatisfaction. Over the years, subscribers have repeatedly complained about dropped calls, slow internet speeds, failed mobile money transactions, and prolonged downtime without compensation.

The company has also come under fire for its steep data and airtime prices, which are among the highest in the region despite Zimbabwes low average incomes. Customers often complain that data bundles mysteriously vanish, while call tariffs rise regularly under the justification of inflation and foreign currency shortages.

Civil society groups, consumer watchdogs, and even government regulators have at different times raised concern about the affordability of Econets services. For instance, while Econet enjoys a dominant market share, its pricing structure has often been accused of putting access to communication beyond the reach of ordinary Zimbabweans.

Econets customer care has also become a lightning rod for anger, with reports of subscribers spending hours without getting through to call centres, and unresolved complaints piling up. This has forced many to vent frustrations on social media platforms, turning #Econet and #DataMustFall into recurring trends.

Analysts say that while the companys 5G and artificial intelligence ambitions may sound impressive, Econet risks alienating its customer base if it does not first address long-standing grievances over affordability and service reliability.

Rolling out 5G is commendable, but it feels like a luxury when the basics  such as consistent 4G coverage, affordable data, and reliable customer care  remain unsolved, said one Harare-based telecoms analyst.

Econet, which has faced financial pressures due to Zimbabwes unstable economy and rising operational costs, insists that its investments in next-generation technologies will eventually filter down to better customer experiences. However, until subscribers see tangible improvements in service quality and fairer pricing, skepticism is likely to overshadow the companys latest digital transformation drive.

news.title: Zanu PF, Opposition Councillors Nearly Exchange Blows During Explosive Meeting
news.content:
By A CorrespondentMasvingo  Tempers flared at a Masvingo City Council meeting on August 25 when a seemingly routine discussion descended into a near-brawl between Zanu PF and opposition councillors.

The chaos began after Councillor Sengerayi Manyanga suggested that the chamber should formally commend government road works in Ward 7. His motion quickly drew backing from fellow Zanu PF councillor Sheron Marombedze.

But the proposal sparked an angry backlash from opposition councillors Wilstaff Sitemere, Alaica Time, and Ester Zishiri, who accused Manyanga of hijacking the council platform for political mileage. This is not a campaign rally. We are here to focus on service delivery, not to heap praise on political parties, one councillor charged, as the heated exchange briefly brought proceedings to a standstill.

The tense standoff underscored the sharp political divisions that continue to undermine council business.

A senior council official later played down the fracas, insisting the matter had been resolved. Yes, there was some shouting and strong words exchanged, but these things happen in council meetings, the official said. What is important is that we managed to continue with business after the incident. Everything is now under control.

news.title: Young Socialite Turns to Bootlicking for Favors From Chivayo …
news.content:
By A Correspondent

Controversial socialite Ritzmcleish Strawbae, born Michelle Moyo, has once again set tongues wagging after releasing a video clip in which she showers excessive praise on First Lady Auxillia Mnangagwa and Lulu Chivayo, wife of flamboyant businessman Wicknell Chivayo.

In the video, which has since gone viral, Ritzmcleish declared her unwavering support for President Emmerson Mnangagwas Vision 2030, saying:

Behind the scenes, ED Huchi. Let us all support Vision 2030. Content Creators for ED.

Her comments immediately sparked public outrage, with critics accusing her of grovelling in hopes of securing financial benefits.

Shes not supporting anyone for free  she just wants a car and cash from Chivayo. This is begging disguised as loyalty, one angry observer remarked.

Analysts say the incident highlights the growing trend of influencers aligning themselves with political elites to gain favors, a practice that has become increasingly visible on Zimbabwes social media landscape.

news.title: Horror As Woman Kills Granddaughter For Rituals
news.content:
Tinotenda Hove  A chilling murder has sent shockwaves across Shurugwi after a 52-year-old woman allegedly killed her four-year-old granddaughter in a suspected ritual act.

Police confirmed that on26 August 2025, officers in Chegutu arrestedVeronica Mudzipuri, an artisanal miner, for the gruesome killing of her granddaughter,Tawanayasha Kadhene.

According to preliminary investigations, Mudzipuri allegedly laced the childs maheu drink with a maize pesticide pill, causing her death. What followed has horrified the community  the suspect is accused of cutting flesh from the victims cheek and mixing it with herbs prescribed by a sangoma before cooking and consuming the concoction.

National police spokesperson Assistant Commissioner Paul Nyathi condemned the act, saying investigations were ongoing. This is a deeply disturbing case. The Zimbabwe Republic Police is treating it with utmost seriousness, and the suspect remains in custody pending court appearance, he said.

Community members in Shurugwi expressed shock and outrage, describing the killing as barbaric and evil. One resident said, We cannot believe that a grandmother, of all people, could commit such an inhumane act against her own blood.

The murder has reignited debate over ritual killings in Zimbabwe, with traditional leaders and human rights groups calling for tougher measures to curb the practice.

Police have urged members of the public to report suspicious activities linked to ritual practices and to resist harmful cultural beliefs that endanger lives

news.title: Four Die In Terrible Crash Along Mutare-Masvingo Road
news.content:
By A Correspondent

Tragedy struck on Thursday along the MutareMasvingo Road when a Toyota Fortuner GD6 overturned, killing four people instantly and leaving three others nursing injuries.

The Zimbabwe Republic Police confirmed the accident, saying it occurred at the 46km peg. According to the police, the vehicle, which was carrying seven passengers, veered off the road before crashing into a concrete signpost. It then rolled several times before finally coming to rest on its roof.

Authorities reported that the bodies of the deceased were taken to Victoria Chitepo Provincial Hospital mortuary, while the three injured survivors were admitted at the same hospital for treatment.

Police have since urged motorists to exercise extreme caution on the countrys highways, warning that reckless driving and speeding continue to claim lives.

news.title: Four Killed, Three Injured in Mutare–Masvingo Road Horror Crash
news.content:
BREAKING NEWS: Four Killed, Three Injured in MutareMasvingo Road Horror Crash.

The once sleek Toyota Fortuner GD6 now lay crumpled into a heap of twisted metal, its roof peeled back like paper, doors ripped apart, and the front end crushed beyond recognition. Shattered glass glittered across the tarmac, mingling with scattered debris, while the vehicles mangled frame sat half-buried in the dirt off the MutareMasvingo Road. Inside, the beige seats hung awkwardly from the wreck, exposed to the open air  a chilling reminder of the violent force that tore through the SUV.

By A Correspondent | MUTARE  Four people died on the spot while three others were seriously injured on Thursday after a Toyota Fortuner GD6 overturned along the MutareMasvingo Road.

The SUV, which was reportedly carrying seven passengers, veered off the highway before overturning, leaving behind a trail of twisted wreckage. The impact crushed the vehicles body beyond recognition, with debris scattered across the crash site.

Witnesses at the scene described the accident as one of the most gruesome in recent months, with survivors pulled from the mangled shell of the Fortuner and rushed to hospital for treatment.

The identities of the deceased have not yet been released, as families are still being informed.

The accident adds to a spate of recent road tragedies on the MutareMasvingo route, one of Zimbabwes busiest and most dangerous highways.

This is a developing story.

news.title: Cash-Strapped Government Funds Mnangagwa’s Extravagant Vatican Visit
news.content:
By A Correspondent

At a time when millions of Zimbabweans are grappling with hunger, collapsing hospitals, and unpaid wages, President Emmerson Mnangagwa has chosen to fly to Vatican City on a State visit to meet Pope Leo XIV.

His foreign adventure, complete with a bloated entourage of senior government officials, has been condemned as a reckless misuse of public funds by a leadership increasingly out of touch with the suffering of its people.

The President left with Foreign Affairs Minister Professor Amon Murwira, Finance Minister Mthuli Ncube, Presidential Communications chief George Charamba, and other top officials.

Observers say the costly trip highlights government extravagance while ordinary citizens endure crippling poverty.

Mnangagwa was seen off at Robert Gabriel Mugabe International Airport by Vice President Kembo Mohadi, Defence Minister Oppah Muchinguri-Kashiri, State Security Minister Lovemore Matuke, Information Minister Jenfan Muswere, Harare Provincial Affairs Minister Charles Tavengwa, service chiefs, and other senior officials. The lavish farewell once again underscored how the ruling elite prioritizes pomp over addressing the hardships at home.

Defending the visit, Prof Murwira said: It is important to deepen our relations with the Vatican as it represents peace and understanding.

But critics argue Mnangagwas government has failed to uphold peace, justice, or dignity within Zimbabwe itself, making such justifications sound hollow.

Meanwhile, Vice President Mohadi has been left as Acting President, a development that many see as a continuation of failed leadership.
